            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>Large stores of carbon are currently immobilized within permafrost, but a warming climate has the potential to release this carbon as dissolved organic carbon into the surrounding environment, with the potential to impact drinking water resources and aquatic health. Dissolved organic carbon (DOC) plays a number of important roles within the environment, ranging from acting as important biogeochemical and nutrient energy sources, to forming carcinogenic disinfection by-products as chlorine is added during water treatment. How DOC reacts is dependent upon its quality, yet little is known about either DOC quality or the fate of DOC in northern environments. The purpose of this research is to understand processes dictating DOC fate in northern aquatic environments in order to help predict how a warming climate could influence DOC quantity and quality. Using a space-for-time approach to represent differences between ‘warmer’ and ‘colder’ areas, water was collected from different aquatic environments including lakes, ponds, creeks, and subsurface peat water from three sites along a latitudinal gradient: Yellowknife, Wekweètì, and Daring Lake. In addition, baseline conditions were to be determined using historical geochemical records of the Yellowknife, Cameron, and Marian rivers. Water samples were analysed for concentrations of DOC and supplementary water quality parameters, in addition to water isotopes. DOC was characterized using ultra-violet and visible absorbance, size-exclusion chromatography, along with other techniques (i.e: PARAFAC and C:N ratios). In addition, laboratory experiments were conducted on select samples to see how easily DOC degrades via microbial or photolytic drivers. A wide range of DOC quality and quantity were encountered, with highest concentrations found in subsurface environments and lower concentrations in surface waters. Measures of DOC quality determined large, aromatic, humic molecules to be present within the subsurface around Yellowkni</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>
            <gmd:credit gco:nilReason="missing"/>

name: 10-25976-hx2s-m606
notes: Large stores of carbon are currently immobilized within permafrost, but a warming climate has the potential to release this carbon as dissolved organic carbon into the surrounding environment, with the potential to impact drinking water resources and aquatic health. Dissolved organic carbon (DOC) plays a number of important roles within the environment, ranging from acting as important biogeochemical and nutrient energy sources, to forming carcinogenic disinfection by-products as chlorine is added during water treatment. How DOC reacts is dependent upon its quality, yet little is known about either DOC quality or the fate of DOC in northern environments. The purpose of this research is to understand processes dictating DOC fate in northern aquatic environments in order to help predict how a warming climate could influence DOC quantity and quality. Using a space-for-time approach to represent differences between ‘warmer’ and ‘colder’ areas, water was collected from different aquatic environments including lakes, ponds, creeks, and subsurface peat water from three sites along a latitudinal gradient: Yellowknife, Wekweètì, and Daring Lake. In addition, baseline conditions were to be determined using historical geochemical records of the Yellowknife, Cameron, and Marian rivers. Water samples were analysed for concentrations of DOC and supplementary water quality parameters, in addition to water isotopes. DOC was characterized using ultra-violet and visible absorbance, size-exclusion chromatography, along with other techniques (i.e: PARAFAC and C:N ratios). In addition, laboratory experiments were conducted on select samples to see how easily DOC degrades via microbial or photolytic drivers. A wide range of DOC quality and quantity were encountered, with highest concentrations found in subsurface environments and lower concentrations in surface waters. Measures of DOC quality determined large, aromatic, humic molecules to be present within the subsurface around Yellowkni

notes_translated.en: Large stores of carbon are currently immobilized within permafrost, but a warming climate has the potential to release this carbon as dissolved organic carbon into the surrounding environment, with the potential to impact drinking water resources and aquatic health. Dissolved organic carbon (DOC) plays a number of important roles within the environment, ranging from acting as important biogeochemical and nutrient energy sources, to forming carcinogenic disinfection by-products as chlorine is added during water treatment. How DOC reacts is dependent upon its quality, yet little is known about either DOC quality or the fate of DOC in northern environments. The purpose of this research is to understand processes dictating DOC fate in northern aquatic environments in order to help predict how a warming climate could influence DOC quantity and quality. Using a space-for-time approach to represent differences between ‘warmer’ and ‘colder’ areas, water was collected from different aquatic environments including lakes, ponds, creeks, and subsurface peat water from three sites along a latitudinal gradient: Yellowknife, Wekweètì, and Daring Lake. In addition, baseline conditions were to be determined using historical geochemical records of the Yellowknife, Cameron, and Marian rivers. Water samples were analysed for concentrations of DOC and supplementary water quality parameters, in addition to water isotopes. DOC was characterized using ultra-violet and visible absorbance, size-exclusion chromatography, along with other techniques (i.e: PARAFAC and C:N ratios). In addition, laboratory experiments were conducted on select samples to see how easily DOC degrades via microbial or photolytic drivers. A wide range of DOC quality and quantity were encountered, with highest concentrations found in subsurface environments and lower concentrations in surface waters. Measures of DOC quality determined large, aromatic, humic molecules to be present within the subsurface around Yellowkni
notes_translated.fr: D'importantes réserves de carbone sont actuellement immobilisées dans le pergélisol, mais le réchauffement climatique pourrait libérer ce carbone sous forme de carbone organique dissous dans l'environnement environnant, ce qui pourrait avoir un impact sur les ressources en eau potable et la santé aquatique. Le carbone organique dissous (COD) joue un certain nombre de rôles importants dans l'environnement, notamment en tant que source d'énergie biogéochimique et nutritive importante ou en formant des sous-produits de désinfection cancérogènes lorsque du chlore est ajouté pendant le traitement de l'eau. La réaction du COD dépend de sa qualité, mais on en sait peu sur la qualité du COD ou sur son devenir dans les environnements nordiques. Le but de cette recherche est de comprendre les processus qui dictent le devenir du COD dans les environnements aquatiques nordiques afin d'aider à prévoir comment le réchauffement climatique pourrait influencer la quantité et la qualité du COD. En utilisant une approche spatio-temporelle pour représenter les différences entre les zones « plus chaudes » et « plus froides », de l'eau a été collectée dans différents environnements aquatiques, notamment des lacs, des étangs, des ruisseaux et de l'eau tourbeuse souterraine à trois sites situés le long d'un gradient latitudinal : Yellowknife, Wekweètì et Daring Lake. De plus, les conditions de référence devaient être déterminées à l'aide des données géochimiques historiques des rivières Yellowknife, Cameron et Marian. Les échantillons d'eau ont été analysés pour déterminer les concentrations de COD et d'autres paramètres de qualité de l'eau, en plus des isotopes de l'eau. Le COD a été caractérisé à l'aide d'une absorbance ultraviolette et visible, d'une chromatographie d'exclusion stérique, ainsi que d'autres techniques (c'est-à-dire le PARAFAC et les ratios C:N). De plus, des expériences en laboratoire ont été menées sur des échantillons sélectionnés afin de déterminer la facilité avec laquelle le COD se dégrade par des facteurs microbiens ou photolytiques. Un large éventail de qualités et de quantités de COD a été observé, les concentrations les plus élevées ayant été observées dans les environnements souterrains et les concentrations les plus faibles dans les eaux de surface. Les mesures de la qualité du COD ont permis de déterminer la présence de grosses molécules humiques aromatiques dans le sous-sol autour de Yellowkni

notes_translation_method.fr: Description text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.

title: CIMP167_ Changes in dissolved organic carbon quality and quantity: Implications for aquatic ecosystems and drinking water quality for northern communities

title_translated.en: CIMP167_ Changes in dissolved organic carbon quality and quantity: Implications for aquatic ecosystems and drinking water quality for northern communities
title_translated.fr: CIMP167_ Modifications de la qualité et de la quantité de carbone organique dissous : implications pour les écosystèmes aquatiques et la qualité de l'eau potable des communautés nordiques
